Executive Summary - City Of Inman Wastewater treatment Plant

1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The City of Inman Wastewater Treatment Plant is located at 1350 Campton Road near Inman, South Carolina.  The facility provides and secondary treatment of wastewater prior to the disinfection of the final effluent before being discharged to the Lawson Fork Creek.  The RMP regulations cover the chlorination and dechlorination processes at this facility which use chlorine and sulfur dioxide, respectively.  The chlorination system provides destruction of pathogenic microorganisms in the wastewater effluent.  The dechlorination system is needed to reduce chlorine residual before discharge to receiving waters.

The City of Inman Wastewater Treatment Plant emergency response policy involves the preparation of an emergency response plan as described in the RMP Management Program and to the emergency response services available in the community.  The emergency response program includes procedures for notification of the National Response Center, City of Inman Fire Department, LEPC (community response plan), and SCDHEC (state response plan).  The City of Inman Wastewater Treatment Plant emergency preparedness program is based upon recommendation of the Water Environment Federation (WEF) and the Chlorine Institute and is in compliance with the EPA Risk Management Emergency Response Program (40 CFR 68.90) requirements.

2.    The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The regulated substances handled and used at the City of Inman Wastewater Treatment Plant are chlorine and sulfur dioxide.

The City of Inman Wastewater Treatment Plant provides biological treatment of sanitary and industrial wastewater generated through out the City's service area.  Chlorine is used in the wastewater treatment process to destroy nuisance and pathogenic microorganisms in the wastewater (i.e., chlorine use as a wastewater disinfectant is an industry standard).

The chlorination process includes chlorine container handling and storage facilities, chlorine feed system (vacuum chlorinators, piping, and injectors), and related safety equipment and instrumentation.

3.    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The City of Inman Wastewater Treatment Plant has in place a prevention program encompassing elements consistent with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard for Highly Hazardous Chemicals (29 CFR 1910.119).  Chlorine is also regulated under the U.S. EPA Clean Air Act 112(r)(7) Accidental Release Prevention Requirements, Risk Management Programs (RMP) (40 CFR Part 68).

The Wastewater Treatment Facility, which is covered under the PSM and RMP standards, has implemented the following:

a.    High level of training for operators and maintenance personnel
b.    Equipment inspection, testing, and preventive maintenance
c.    Use of "industry standard" process and safety equipment
d.    Use of accurate and effective operating procedures
f.    Performance of hazard review of equipment and procedures
g.    Implementation of an internal and external auditing program
h.    Segregation of chemical processes for compatibility and fire prevention/control
i.    Chlorine leak detectors and alarm system
j.    Availability of SCBAs and chlorine container leak repair kit
k.    Maintenance of approved parts inventory

4.    Five Year Accident History

During the past five years the City of Inman Wastewater Treatment Plant has had no chemical releases which created an emergency situation outside the plant boundaries nor resulted in any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

5.    The Emergency Response Program

The City of Inman Wastewater Treatment Plant has "Emergency Procedures" in place to inform the employee how to communicate with local age

ncies and how to respond to an accidental release.  Plant personnel are trained in emergency procedures and emergency notifications.  Trained personnel respond to emergencies in their area with the local fire department as a back-up.  Inman's Emergency Response Program has been discussed with the county Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the City fire department to ensure good communication and operational effectiveness.

6.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The City of Inman Wastewater Treatment Plant plans to continue to evaluate the regulated process as required under the PSM/RMP standards to ensure safe operations.
